thread.title: Spurrier sounded spent after LSU loss
thread.title_full: Spurrier sounded spent after LSU loss

title: Spurrier sounded spent after LSU loss
text:
Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest Spurrier sounded spent after LSU loss BATON ROUGE, La. -- Spurrier said he was considering resigning earlier this season, but LSU apparently pushed him over the edge in a 45-24 victory on Saturday. Post to Facebook Spurrier sounded spent after LSU loss BATON ROUGE, La. -- Spurrier said he was considering resigning earlier this season, but LSU apparently pushed him over the edge in a 45-24 victory on Saturday.  //on.wwltv.com/1Lt9Jrj   Spurrier sounded spent after LSU loss Glenn Guilbeau / Gannett Louisiana 7:26 p.m. CDT October 13, 2015 Head coach Les Miles of the LSU Tigers greets head coach Steve Spurrier of the South Carolina Gamecocks at midfield prior to a game at Tiger Stadium on October 10, 2015 in Baton Rouge, Louisiana. (Photo: Stacy Revere) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
BATON ROUGE, La. -- Spurrier said he was considering resigning earlier this season, but LSU apparently pushed him over the edge in a 45-24 victory on Saturday. 
Spurrier officially announced on Tuesday that he was resigning following 30 seasons and one part of a 31st season as a head coach with stops at Tampa Bay in the USFL, Duke, Florida, Washington in the NFL and South Carolina. 
The last game Spurrier, 70, ever coached apparently was at Tiger Stadium, and at times he sounded defeatist and seemed ready to throw in his visor in the postgame press conference. 
“I think we have a team next week that maybe we match up a little better with,” he said sarcastically, referring to the Gamecocks’ opponent on Saturday – Vanderbilt, which historically has been the Southeastern Conference’s worst team and is 2-3 overall and 0-2 in the league. 
“We just aren’t as talented as we have been in years past,” Spurrier went on. “I get frustrated watching our guys. They run in there and nobody tackles them, and they fall down. Their guys must have broken eight tackles on their big runs. Our guys go in there and just fall on the ground. Nobody tackles them. That’s just the way we are I guess. We are a struggling bunch.” 
This was not the first time that a loss to LSU gave a coach a sense of finality. 
“This was the worst beating we’ve taken since the 1960s,” Alabama coach Bear Bryant said after No. 11 LSU defeated the No. 8 Tide, 20-10, on Nov. 6, 1982, in Legion Field in Birmingham, Alabama. It was Bryant’s first loss to LSU since 1970, and he soon began considering retirement. He lost his next two, including his first loss to Auburn since 1972. He announced his resignation that December and died the following January. 
MILES ON CHUBB: Without being asked, LSU coach Les Miles expressed his sorrow for injured Georgia tailback Nick Chubb at his press luncheon on Monday. 
Chubb, a sophomore from Cedartown, Georgia, who was the SEC freshman of the year last season and a freshman All-American, tore ligaments in his knee on Saturday in a loss to Tennessee and is out for the season. 
“I am kind of taken back a little by Nick Chubb,” Miles said. “I’m just sad to have injury there. You see guys fight like heck to have excellence and to play at a very high level. Injury is the one thing about this sport that you’d like to get fixed. It’s the same thing that makes it great, because you have to overcome it. But guys that are deserving, you’d like for them not ever to be injured. So I wish Nick Chubb the very best.” 
QUOTE OF THE DAY: “Well, we almost won one or two of them. We didn’t almost win this one.” 
---South Carolina coach Steve Spurrier on the first – and last – 0-4 start in the SEC of his coaching career Saturday after the LSU game. Read or Share this story: http://on.wwltv.com/1Lt9Jrj TOP VIDEOS
